newsitem.title: USA: Clinton tells advisers be "flexible" in budget.
newsitem.headline: Clinton tells advisers be "flexible" in budget.

text.p: Senior White House budget negotiators were headed to Capitol Hill Tuesday for talks with congressional budget leaders with orders from President Clinton to be "flexible" in negotiating a balanced budget deal.

Office of Management and Budget Director Franklin Raines, congressional liaison John Hilley and National Economic Council Chairman Gene Sperling were to meet chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees at 2 p.m. (1800 GMT), the White House said.
"They are under instructions from the president and from the chief of staff to be flexible in the pursuit of a balanced budget agreement," White House spokesman Mike McCurry said.

Asked what he meant, McCurry told reporters: "I think that we understand that we're going to have show some flexibility if we want to achieve a balanced budget agreement. The president wants to work with this Republican Congress to achieve a balanced budget agreement."
Senate Republican Leader Trent Lott complained Sunday that Clinton's 1996 campaign finance scandal may be delaying progress toward a balanced budget agreement.
He said he was disappointed and waiting for serious negotiations to begin on a package to balance the budget by 2002.
